column1: Mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid bone of the skull.
Mastoiditis is most often caused by a middle ear infection (acute otitis media).
The infection may spread from the ear to the mastoid bone.
Before antibiotics, mastoiditis was one of the leading causes of death in children.

- Drainage from the ear - Ear pain or discomfort - Fever, may be high or suddenly increase - Headache - Hearing loss - Redness of the ear or behind the ear - Swelling behind ear, may cause ear to stick out
The following tests may show an abnormality of the mastoid bone: - CT scan of the ear - Head CT scan A culture of drainage from the ear may show bacteria.
The infection is treated with antibiotic injections, followed by antibiotics taken by mouth.
Surgery to drain the middle ear through the eardrum (myringotomy) may be needed to treat the middle ear infection.
Call your health care provider if you have symptoms of mastoiditis.
